head.title: May 14-20; Giuliani Abandons Campaign For U.S. Senate Seat

hedline.hl1: May 14-20; Giuliani Abandons Campaign For U.S. Senate Seat

block.p: What would a week in New York be without at least one jolting development in the race for United States Senate? So it was that on Friday, four days after Hillary Rodham Clinton was formally designated as the Democratic candidate at her party's convention in Albany, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani quit the race at a packed-to-the-rafters news conference.

In the end, the only real surprise was how long Mr. Giuliani took to make the decision, which came after three weeks in which it was revealed that he was suffering from prostate cancer, that he had struck up a close relationship with a woman who wasn't his wife and that he was seeking a separation from his wife, Donna Hanover, after 16 years of marriage.

Mr. Giuliani said he needed to devote all his energy to deciding on a course of treatment and running the city. The Republican Party quickly turned to the future: at week's end,the most likely replacement for Mr. Giuliani was Rep. Rick A. Lazio, a Long Island Republican.
